Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: A Probate and Family Court may modify an existing custody and parenting-time judgment when there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances and modification is in the best interests of the child.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states the statutory standard governing modification of custody orders under G.L. c. 208, § 28: there must be a material and substantial change in circumstances and the modification must be in the best interests of the children. The court applies this standard to uphold the judge’s finding of a material and substantial change (mother’s rehabilitation) and then analyzes whether the resulting custody arrangement serves the children’s best interests. This directly supports the proposition about the Probate and Family Court’s authority and the governing criteria for modification.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 1993, c. 460, enables a Probate Court judge, upon finding that ‘a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred’ to modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody arrangements of minor children, where the modification ‘is necessary in the best interests of the children.’ … When determining child custody awards in general, or modifications of custody awards based on changed circumstances, the guiding principle always has been the best interests of the children.”

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).proposition: A Probate and Family Court may modify an existing custody and parenting-time judgment when there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances and modification is in the best interests of the child.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).support_reasoning: The quoted concurrence focuses on statutory interpretation under G.L. c. 209C in the context of an initial paternity/custody/visitation determination after the mother had already relocated. It discusses the judge’s lack of authority to order the mother and child back to Massachusetts and how custody and visitation should be fashioned under § 10, but it does not address the standard for *modifying* an existing custody and parenting-time judgment based on a material and substantial change in circumstances. The familiar Massachusetts modification standard and best-interests analysis are not the subject of the holding here, so this case does not provide authority for that proposition.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).relevant_excerpt: “After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate.”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: In making or modifying custody orders, the “best interests of the child” standard governs.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: In making or modifying custody orders, the “best interests of the child” standard governs.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The court squarely addresses the governing standard for custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10(a), and explains that custody of nonmarital children is to be awarded as appropriate in the “best interests of the child.” The opinion further traces the historical use of the best-interests standard in Massachusetts custody and visitation law, and applies that standard to affirm the custody order here. This directly supports the proposition that custody orders are governed by the best interests of the child standard.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “Section 10 (a) gives a probate judge the power to award custody of nonmarital children ‘to the mother or the father or to them jointly … as may be appropriate in the best interests of the child.’ … In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… and has been adhered to ever since.”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: In making or modifying custody orders, the “best interests of the child” standard governs.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion is a custody decision that repeatedly frames the inquiry in terms of what arrangements are appropriate for the child, with explicit references to "best interests" via the statutes it applies. It relies on G.L. c. 208, § 31, which expressly uses a "best interest of the child" standard for determining custody and discusses factors (like domestic violence) that must be considered within that best‑interests framework. Although the case focuses more on requiring explicit findings about domestic violence than on articulating the best‑interests test itself, it clearly proceeds on the premise that custody determinations are governed by that standard.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 208, § 31, provides that "[i]f, despite the prior or current issuance of a restraining order against one parent pursuant to chapter two hundred and nine A, the court orders shared legal or physical custody . . . the court shall provide written findings to support such shared custody order." ... To the same effect, see the definition of "[s]hared physical custody," G. L. c. 208, § 31 (1994 ed.): "In determining whether temporary shared legal custody would not be in the best interest of the child, the court shall consider . . . whether any member of the family has been the perpetrator of domestic violence."

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: In making or modifying custody orders, the “best interests of the child” standard governs.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that under G.L. c. 208, § 28, a judgment modifying custody must be based both on a material and substantial change in circumstances and that the modification is necessary in the best interests of the children. The court repeatedly frames the custody modification analysis in terms of whether the transfer of custody will be conducive to the child’s welfare, i.e., the child’s best interests. Thus, it directly affirms that the best interests standard governs custody orders and their modification.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28 (‘the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children’).”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: Education and school attendance are central components of a child’s welfare and best interests, and a parent’s interference with schooling and educational progress may warrant modification of existing custody and parenting-time orders.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses custody and visitation under a broad “best interests of the child” standard, and notes that the parents disagree on major child‑rearing issues including schooling and education, but it does not treat education or school attendance as a central or distinct component of welfare. Nor does it involve a modification of existing custody or parenting‑time orders based on interference with schooling or educational progress. Education is mentioned only as one of several areas of disagreement, not as the basis for modifying or structuring custody or visitation.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found the wife has been the ‘primary nurturing parent’ and ‘primary caretaker’ and that the children have the ‘strongest bond’ with their mother. These factors are highly significant for the welfare of the children... the judge concluded that because the parties have basic fundamental differences in the major areas of child rearing, such as health care, religion and education, as well as in day-to-day decision making and philosophy of discipline, an order providing joint custody would run contrary to the children’s happiness and welfare.”

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, custody and parenting-time orders must at all times serve the best interests of the child.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly frames the trial judge’s task, once unfitness is established, as determining what arrangement is in the child’s best interests, and it does so by direct reference to the governing Massachusetts statutes. The SJC describes the ‘best interests of the child’ as the controlling and flexible standard in custody and adoption placement decisions under G.L. c. 210, § 3, confirming that custody/placement orders must serve that best‑interests standard at all times. This aligns with the claimed proposition about Massachusetts law governing custody and parenting‑time orders.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).relevant_excerpt: “Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). … Rather, we adhere to our view that in child custody cases the best interests standard mandated by G. L. c. 210, § 3, is ‘a flexible one,’ and the weight to be accorded its several considerations…‘will vary with the circumstances.’”

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: Modification of the existing Judgment to protect Emily’s school attendance and educational progress is necessary to serve her best interests and to prevent further educational harm.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The case concerns relocation of children out of the Commonwealth under G.L. c. 208, § 30 and articulates the “real advantage” standard for removal, focusing on best interests generally, not on modification of a judgment to protect school attendance or prevent educational harm. While the opinion mentions that the children will receive excellent schooling in Greece, it does not address modifying an existing judgment to safeguard a child’s current educational placement or progress. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific proposition claimed.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life), the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent, and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”
